THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 268(d)(2), SCACR
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

  
    
      
        Donald S.
          Becker, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South
          Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Benjamin H. Culbertson, Trial Judge
Â Larry B. Hyman, Jr., Post-Conviction
Judge

Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2010-MO-025
  Submitted October 7, 2010 â€“ Filed October
11, 2010 

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Deputy Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, South Carolina
          Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for
          Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Christina J. Catoe, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â 
  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari to review an order denying his
  application for post-conviction relief (PCR) and granting him a belated review of his direct appeal issues
  pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35 (1974).
Petitioner was convicted of criminal domestic violence of a high
  and aggravated nature (CDVHAN) and sentenced to ten yearsâ€™ imprisonment.Â  No
  direct appeal was taken.Â  Thereafter, petitioner filed a PCR application
  alleging he was denied his right to a direct appeal because plea counsel failed
  to properly perfect an appeal after petitioner asked counsel to do so.[1]Â  The PCR judge found that petitioner
  did not knowingly and voluntarily waive his right to a direct appeal.Â  
Because there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s
  finding that petitioner did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to
  a direct appeal, we grant the petition for a writ of certiorari, dispense with
  further briefing, and proceed with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant
  to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).
FACTS
On
  September 24, 2007, the victim gave a statement to police indicating that
  petitioner hit her on the elbows, knees, and head with an â€œiron barâ€ and choked
  her until she could barely breathe.Â  The victim further stated that she jumped
  into a nearby lake to get away from petitioner.Â  At trial, the victim recanted her statement
  and testified that petitioner did not attack her, and her head injury was the
  result of a fall.[2]Â 
  The victim also stated that she fell into the lake and did not jump in to avoid
  petitioner.Â  
The victim
  acknowledged giving a statement to police indicating that petitioner attacked
  her, but she testified that she lied to the police because she and petitioner
  were fighting and she was angry.Â  The victim stated that, on the day of the
  incident, she wanted the police to arrest petitioner because she was drunk and
  angry and afraid petitioner was going to leave her.Â  
The victim
  admitted being an alcoholic and using drugs and testified that she did not
  remember what she told the police.Â  The victim testified that, at the time of
  the attack, she had been drinking vodka for four days, and she commonly â€œblacks
  outâ€ when she drinks.Â  The victim stated that on several occasions she has
  injured herself by falling.Â  
Georgetown
  County Sherriffâ€™s Deputy John Magann testified that he responded to the alleged
  assault.Â  Officer Magann testified that, upon his arrival at the scene, he
  observed an injury to the victimâ€™s forehead and noticed that the victimâ€™s
  clothing was â€œsoaking wet.â€Â  Officer Magann stated that the victim appeared
  â€œhighly upsetâ€ and smelled of alcohol.Â  Officer Magann testified the victim
  informed him that she had been drinking, but she did not believe she was
  drunk.Â  The victim told Officer Magann that petitioner inflicted her head
  injuries with an iron bar and choked her until she could barely breathe and
  that she jumped in the nearby lake to get away from petitioner.Â  Officer Magann
  stated that he did not observe any marks, scratches or bruising around the victimâ€™s
  neck, but, based on his ten years of experience as a first responder, the
  victimâ€™s head injuries were consistent with being inflicted by a metal pipe.Â  
Officer
  Magann testified that he followed the victim to the area where the incident
  occurred[3] to look for petitioner and other evidence of the crime.Â  Officer Magann stated
  that he observed charred remnants of a steel-framed tent, but he did not find
  petitioner or any piece of pipe appearing to have been used in the attack.Â  He
  also testified that he did not observe any sharp objects on the embankment
  leading to the nearby lake.Â  
Donna
  Roberts, an emergency room nurse at Waccamaw Community Hospital, testified that
  she treated the victim on the day of the incident.Â  Roberts testified that when
  the victim arrived at the hospital, her clothes were soaking wet, she was
  bloody, and she had leaves and twigs in her hair.Â  Roberts testified that the
  victim had two wounds on her headâ€”one on her forehead and another on the top of
  her head.[4]Â 
  Roberts stated that the victimâ€™s medical records reflected no other trauma,
  bruising, or tenderness on her elbows or knees.Â  
Roberts
  further stated that the victim appeared to be intoxicated and under duress.Â 
  Roberts testified that, in spite of the intoxication, the victim appeared to
  understand her questions and respond appropriately, and did not appear to have
  difficulty recalling how she became injured.Â  Roberts testified that the victim
  told her that she had been hit in the head with a lead pipe by her boyfriend.Â 
  Roberts stated that the victimâ€™s injuries were consistent with being inflicted
  by a pipe and were inconsistent with falling down.Â  
Prior
  to the jury charge, petitioner objected to the trial courtâ€™s proposed CDVHAN
  instruction, arguing it improperly instructed the jury that the State could
  prove an accompanying element of aggravation by demonstrating a disparity in
  the ages or physical condition of the parties or a difference in gender.Â 
  Petitioner argued such an instruction was improper 

under S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 16-25-65 (Supp. 2009) and asked the trial court to charge the jury under
  the plain language of the statute, which does not reference aggravating
  circumstances.Â  
The
  trial court denied petitionerâ€™s motion and thereafter instructed the jury on
  CDVHAN as follows:

  In order to convict [petitioner] of [CDVHAN] the State must prove
    beyond a reasonable doubt that [petitioner] caused physical injury to a member
    of [petitionerâ€™s] own household accompanied by circumstances of aggravation.
  . . .
  Circumstances of aggravation can include a great disparity in
    the ages or physical condition of the parties, a difference in gender, serious bodily injury to the victim or the use of a deadly weapon.

(emphasis added).Â Â  
ISSUE
Did the trial
  court erroneously instruct the jury on the offense of CDVHAN?
DISCUSSION
Petitioner argues the trial courtâ€™s jury
  instructions on CDVHAN improperly expanded the definition of the offense,
  permitting the jury to convict on aggravating circumstances that were supported
  by the facts of the case but not intended by the legislature.Â  We agree.
An
  appellate court will not reverse a trial judgeâ€™s decision about jury
  instructions absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 647 S.E.2d
  144 (2007).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs where the trial courtâ€™s ruling is
  based on an error of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without
  evidentiary support.Â  Id.
The
  trial judge is required to charge the current and correct law of South
  Carolina.Â  State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 589 S.E.2d 1 (2003).Â  A trial
  court commits reversible error where it instructs the jury on elements that are
  not included in the statutory offense.Â  State v. Rothell, 301 S.C. 168,
  391 S.E.2d 228 (1990) (finding reversible error where a trial court instructed
  the jury on an issue that was not an element of the statutory offense because
  the jury could have been misled).Â  
To
  warrant reversal, a trial judgeâ€™s charge must be both erroneous and
  prejudicial.Â  Taylor, supra.Â  If a jury instruction is deemed
  erroneous, the Court must determine whether there is a reasonable likelihood
  that the jury applied the improper instruction in a way that violates the
  constitution.Â  Tate v. State, 351 S.C. 418, 570 S.E.2d 522 (2002).Â  Due
  process forbids the State to convict a person of a crime without proving the
  elements of that crime beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Bunkley v. Florida,
  538 U.S. 835 (2003).Â  
In
  determining whether an erroneous instruction is prejudicial, the evidence will
  be construed in the light most favorable to the accused.Â  State v. Bradley,
  126 S.C. 528, 120 S.E. 240 (1923).Â  An insubstantial error not affecting the
  result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by
  competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.Â  State
    v. Pagan, 369 S.C. 201, 631 S.E.2d 262 (2006).Â Â Â  
South
  Carolina Code Â§ 16-25-65(A) states that a person is guilty of CDVHAN when a
  person commits one of the following:

  
    (1) an assault and battery which involves the use of a deadly
      weapon or results in serious
      bodily injury to the victim; or
    (2) an
      assault, with or without an accompanying battery, which would reasonably cause
      a person to fear imminent serious bodily injury or death.
  


S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-65(A)
  (Supp. 2009).Â  Although the statute formerly incorporated the elements of
  assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN),[5] the statute was amended in 2003, and the language incorporating ABHAN was
  removed.
Petitioner argues the trial courtâ€™s charge improperly led to a
  guilty verdict because it allowed the jury to convict on factual elements of
  the case that were not contemplated by the legislature.Â  Specifically,
  petitioner claims that â€œa great disparity in the ages or physical condition of
  the partiesâ€ and â€œa difference in genderâ€ are not proper elements upon which a
  jury may convict a person of CDVHAN.Â  
 In
  return, the State argues that the jury instructions, on the whole, charged the
  correct law, including the elements involving serious bodily injury and the use
  of a deadly weapon.Â  However, the State argues that, assuming the jury charge
  was improper, any error did not contribute to the verdict and did not prejudice
  petitioner because the State presented overwhelming evidence of petitionerâ€™s
  guilt on the proper elements of CDVHAN.Â  
The
  trial courtâ€™s jury instruction amounted to an error of law because it permitted
  the jury to convict petitioner of CDVHAN based on a finding that petitioner
  caused physical harm to the victim, coupled with a difference in gender or a
  disparity in age or physical condition, which are not elements of the statutory
  offense.Â  See Bunkley, supra; Pittman, supra; Taylor, supra; Tate, supra; Rothell, supra.Â 
  There is no way to determine from the record whether the jury found petitioner
  guilty based on a proper finding that petitioner inflicted serious bodily
  injury or used a deadly weapon, or whether the jury found petitioner merely
  caused some physical harm accompanied by a difference in gender or a disparity
  in age or physical condition, which are not proper elements of CDVHAN.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-65(A) (Supp. 2009).Â  
Further,
  construing the evidence in the light most favorable to petitioner, the jury
  could have found petitioner guilty of the lesser included offense of simple
  criminal domestic violence (CDV).[6]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-10(A) (Supp. 2009); Bradley, supra.Â 
  Despite the victimâ€™s statement to police that petitioner hit her on her knees
  and elbows and strangled her, Officer Magann testified that he observed no
  marks on the victimâ€™s neck, and the victimâ€™s medical chart indicated no trauma
  on her body aside from the two head wounds.Â  Further, Nurse Roberts testified
  that head wounds bleed profusely if one of the many blood vessels in the head
  is damaged.
Construing
  that evidence in the light most favorable to petitioner, the jury could have
  attributed the excessive amount of blood to the fact that the wound was located
  on the victimâ€™s head, and the jury reasonably could have determined that
  petitioner caused some physical harm, but did not seriously injure the victim
  or use a deadly weapon.Â  Thus, had the
  CDVHAN charge not improperly included â€œa disparity in the ages or physical
  condition of the partiesâ€ or â€œa difference in genderâ€ as aggravating
  circumstances, the jury may have found petitioner not guilty of CDVHAN, but
  guilty of the lesser included offense of CDV.Â  Accordingly, because it is unclear whether the jury found
  each element of CDVHAN beyond a reasonable doubt, and the erroneous jury
  instruction was not harmless beyond a reasonable doubt, the instruction
  constitutes reversible error.Â  See Bunkley, supra; Pagan, supra; Taylor, supra; Tate, supra; Rothell, supra. 
Because
  resolution of this issue is dispositive, we decline to address the remaining
  issues raised by petitioner.Â  See State v. Allen, 370 S.C. 88,
  634 S.E.2d 653 (2006) (declining to address remaining issues where resolution
  of prior issue is dispositive).
CONCLUSION
Because
  the trial courtâ€™s jury instruction amounted to an error of law and the
  erroneous jury instruction was not harmless beyond a reasonable doubt,
  petitionerâ€™s conviction is
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., PLEICONES, BEATTY, KITTREDGE and HEARN, JJ., concur.

[1] The State conceded that
  petitioner was denied his right to a direct appeal.Â  
[2] During the victimâ€™s testimony, the trial judge
  instructed petitioner to discontinue signaling answers to the witness.Â 
  Further, we note the victim was granted immunity for lying under oath.Â  
[3] The victim told Officer Magann that the incident
  occurred where she, petitioner, and another man lived in a tent near a lake in
  Murrells Inlet.Â  Initially, the three lived in a metal-framed tent, but that
  tent burned, and they thereafter crafted another tent by tying a rope between
  two trees and draping a mesh tarp over it.Â  
[4] Roberts testified that the wound on the victimâ€™s
  forehead was about two inches long, and the hospital staff was easily able to
  control the bleeding from that wound.Â  However, Roberts stated that the wound
  on the top of the victimâ€™s head was about three inches long and bled profusely
  for some time.Â  Roberts stated that the head is very venous, and bleeding can
  be difficult to control if you â€œnickâ€ one of the many veins in the head.Â  
[5]ABHAN is defined as an unlawful act of violent injury
  to the person of another, accompanied by circumstances of aggravation, such as
  the use of a deadly weapon, the infliction of serious bodily injury, the intent
  to commit a felony, the great disparity of the ages and physical conditions of
  the parties, a difference in sexes, indecent liberties or familiarities with a
  female, the purposeful infliction of shame and disgrace, resistance to lawful
  authorities, and others.Â  See State v. Jones, 133 S.C. 167, 130
  S.E. 747 (1925), overruled on other grounds by State v. Foust,
  325 S.C. 12, 479 S.E.2d 50 (1996).
[6] The jury was instructed on CDV.Â

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks
  a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for post-conviction
  relief (PCR).
The
  petition is denied as to petitionerâ€™s Question 2.Â  However, because there is
  sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner did not
  knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we grant the
  petition for a writ of certiorari on petitionerâ€™s Question 1, dispense with further
  briefing, and proceed with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis
    v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).

Petitionerâ€™s
  appeal is dismissed, after review pursuant to Anders v. California, 386
  U.S. 738 (1967).Â  Counselâ€™s motion to be relieved is granted. 
DISMISSED.

TOAL,
  C.J., PLEICONES, BEATTY, KITTREDGE and HEARN, JJ., concur.
